Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: Very few. It was a horrible class.

different economics methods to valuate environmental resources
different perspectives on valuing environmental resources
This course gave me a strong understanding of how economic concepts can be used to analyze various environmental issues and policies.
I gained a better understanding of how different policy tools are used to address various environmental issues and learned about the economic implications/reasoning behind them.

I learned fundamental microeconomics skills that are relevant to environmental economics and policy. I have a good grasp of the key theories and principles underpinning economic policy, and I believe I can explain it in a digestible manner to anyone who is not as familiar with the subject matter.

I now understand what goes into policy decisions, the tradeoffs made, and how they are arrived at. It was great to study how policies take into account the interests of firms, individuals and public authority.
Good review of environmental economics with some healthy criticism of the tools used (e.g. cost-benefit analysis)
Learned useful tools such as CBA, principles of discounting, Forest and Fisheries economics
I developed insight into relevant environmental economics and policy that I can draw upon for arguments in environmental law.

This class offered a great introduction to environmental economics concepts that have helped to change the way I think about environmental issues. It was helpful to learn about the different drivers of environmental and resource decisions, especially when considering different players' perspectives and the costs and benefits of different decisions. I enjoyed learning more about the methodologies behind various economic studies.

A better understanding of cost-benefit analyses, how to internalize pollution externalities, how to manage open-access goods, efficient extraction of renewable and non-renewable resources, and more. Basically, a great overview course of environmental economics concepts that will serve me well in the policy world!
Understanding of key policy tools like cap and trade, carbon tax, subsidies, and of forces affecting markets.
I learned how decisionmakers use economics to evaluate environmental policies.
Cost benefit analysis, natural resources extraction models, valuation methods for environmental resources,
I gained an understanding of the economics around natural resources. We used different models and methods which helped create a cohesive understanding.
I resolidified some previous knowledge about resource economics and learned some new things too.
Fundamental knowledge of environmental economic concepts.

1. Policy instruments to address different environmental challenges eg pollution, over fishing, 
2. Valuation of NR using economic models, tools
3. Policy instruments to manage non-renewable resources

Further understanding of basic microeconomics behavior with application towards pressing environmental questions of our time. Ability to evaluate efficiency in many different contexts, including abatement vs pollution, time waiting vs value (forests), effort vs revenue (fisheries), Hotelling model, and others. 

Different economic valuation tools for non-market values, classification of different types of nonmarket values

Really important conversations about considering efficiency vs equity, objectivity vs subjectivity, trade-offs and benefit cost analysis.
Basics of evaluating policy from an economics perspective.
Great for someone who is new to environmental policies in action and want to learn economic analyses behind them
An enhanced understanding of the basic microeconomic principles covered in the fall foundations course, a greater appreciation of the factors that influence policymaking

I learned a range of environmental economics topics- including cap and trade programs work, forest and fishery economics, and the theories behind environmental decision-making, including cost-benefit analyses and pollution abatement curves.
The topics covered in class were highly relevant and I am already applying them in my summer internship.

I was extremely underwhelmed. This course did not demand the rigor or excellence that I would expect of a required core class. Professor Kotchen frequently got material wrong in the slides and on the board, and he did not demand excellence from us. I was thoroughly disappointed.
very well
The knowledge and skills I learned in this course aligned very well with my expectations.
Very well

I expected the class to give me the foundations to environmental economics, and it delivered. Matt was clear that we were not going to be extremely technical, which took off some of the pressure in the initial weeks. I think I will be able to retain the knowledge and skills so that I can handle higher level classes in natural resource economics.
The class aligned well with my expectations. Despite the fact that I found certain topics very specific to fields I may never find myself working in. eg: forests and fisheries
A good foundational course
Very well
Aligned well with my expectations.
I took Professor Kotchen's half-semester course last semester so I had a good idea about what to expect for this class, and it aligned with those expectations.
Very well!
Very well.
I learned more in this class than I expected to. I have a much deeper understanding of environmental economics now.
Very good, although it was a little superficial at times given the amount of topics covered
The course gave me a solid foundation in economics with application to environmental management. I benefited from understanding the different hypotheses and models.
Very well.
This course aligned with my expectations in terms of what I hoped to learn, and I also ended up enjoying it more than I had expected.
The course was relevant for policy and practice. The material covered met my expectations although most of the examples drew on US experience with limited international experiences to learn from.
Very well.
Well. The only way it could've been improved would've been by attempting a BCA or other econ assessment. Even a basic one would've helped solidify the concepts.
Very well

This class exceeded my expectations. It enhanced my understanding of the economic mechanics of policymaking, gave me greater insight into specific policy areas, and made me feel more informed on environmental issues generally.
I think the knowledge and insights I gained aligned well with my expectations, though I'm not sure how useful the forest/fisheries economics aspect of the course will be for me.
Expectations were surpassed!

It needs to be in a more comfortable, spacious room. It needs to demand excellence and rigor. Professor Kotchen needs to call on other students - not just the tall white men who sat in the front. Deeply frustrating class experience - perhaps my worst at FES.

the course material was very interesting, and most of the readings were great (excepting the on 45 page reading which was a bit excessive)
I do wish the final was worth a little less

This workload for this this course was very predictable and reasonable, which I really appreciate.  There are weekly problem sets which align well with the material covered in the class and take a very reasonable amount of time.  There was also a perfect mix of learning economic concepts and having class discussions about policy implications.  
The class should definitely be placed in a larger room next year, because it was a very tight squeeze.  I also found that there was not enough time given for the midterm.
Overall, great class!
I appreciated the focus on real world problems but felt we focused too much specifically on Kotchen's previous work (e.g. an entire lecture on the Maine water issue).

I was initially intimidated by the readings, but the lectures and office hours helped to break down the course material such that it was simple enough for all levels. I appreciate that Matt and Ethan made themselves available beyond the usual sessions so that we could ask any questions we had about the material. I did not interact much with the other TA, Zihan, but he provided timely feedback on our problem sets. 

I would have liked to learn more about how various economic models are constructed so that I would be able to contribute to such modeling in internships or further research. We got a brief overview. I think there should also be options for further reading and discussion beyond the material we canvassed in class so that we have a greater depth of understanding.

Class discussions were very interesting and facilitated learning, however, I believe course material, eg lecture slides can be made more comprehensive to facilitate learning outside of the classroom. Sometimes the pace of the class is very fast to keep up with and not having very comprehensive slides doesn't help with catching up. This is a class that should definitely be recorded.

Matt Kotchen is an engaging and approachable professor. His occasional jokes help lighten the mood on what can be a relatively dry topic on economic theory. Professor Kotchen has also done a good job in bringing in relevant case studies to analyze using the economic tools discussed in class.
The course is a little fast paced and it would be helpful to have it video recorded so that the students could have access to these videos for going back to review concepts later.

A weakness is that class does not necessarily align well with problem sets and exams as far as mathematical applications. While I understand we are meant to work through problems on our own and apply concepts beyond what is taught in class, it would still be helpful to have more related material taught in class.

This was a very interesting, fun course to take. Professor Kotchen especially brought a lot of energy to the class and is clearly very happy to share his knowledge with students. I appreciated his flexible teaching style so that we could move things quickly that the class understood immediately, or we could slow things down if needed. I also greatly appreciate that Professor Kotchen asked students what we were interested in learning and incorporated our suggestions into the class.

The only thing I think could be improved is integrating more of the graphs into the slides. I understand that many are complex and it is better to draw them out while explaining each step to the class, but I missed one class because I was sick and so completely lost out on an entire chunk of knowledge for a section. I am not a Forestry student and so didn't know anyone in the class, thus didn't have anyone to ask for notes for the day I missed. This, perhaps, is a problem that affects few students, but I think including even a couple of basic graphs in the slides could be very useful for review before tests, too.

Overall I liked how the class is structured in terms of how concepts are introduced and how the problem sets are designed. Some of the topics towards the end of the class (e.g. strong vs weak sustainability and genuine savings) seemed more abstract and harder to grasp than other topics in the class, and we went through them quite quickly. It might be helpful to make those concepts more concrete and to bring in more examples to make sure that students understand what they're all about. Also, I pretty much only interacted with Ethan as far as the TAs went, and he was an excellent instructor and extremely patient with questions.
No improvements that I can think it -- really loved the class and learned a lot!
Engaging professor, great TAs
The course is structured and taught very well. I wouldn't change anything.

More mathematical formulation would be better but at the same time it only focuses on the concepts which is important. Takes a long time to explain the same basic concepts which would be an opportunity to go deeper or more technical

I think given the amount of time problem sets, they should be given more weight in final grading. That said I thought they were great for having us take the tools discussed and utilize them to gain familiarity.
The material is interesting and well delivered by Professor Kotchen. Ethan is an amazing TA.

I felt that this course gave a good refresher on basic econ as well as an intro to some of the main ideas and problems that environmental economists work on. To me this felt like a well-designed and thought-out course that did what it set out to do. 

My only criticisms relate to the problem sets. The way that some of the questions were worded made it very hard to figure out how to answer them, at least at first when I was figuring out what the TAs were looking for. Towards the end I also felt like the grading had become a little inconsistent. 

However, I really appreciated how available the TAs made themselves in office hours and how patient they were with the students. I also liked that Prof. Kotchen encourages group work on the problem sets, since I felt like I learned a lot more by discussing the concepts with others versus just trying to think it through alone.

I think the course tries to cover too much material in one semester which gives students which limits students ability to have a comprehensive engagement with the materials. I also think that the evaluation structure adopted focuses more on problem sets than actual learning. I would recommend that in future, a different model eg give problem questions to students and let them research and report back through presentations or written papers.

Matt's teaching style is my favorite I've encountered at FES thus far. He really cares so much that his students are inspired by and invested in the process of learning, and considers all questions as a learning opportunity for the rest of the class. Class was fun almost all days.

Matt was an engaged professor and the TAs were great, so I got a lot out of lectures. The level of conversation for a Monday morning econ class was impressive. Could've benefited from a professor-led policy assignment of sorts (something meatier than a problem set) at the end of the class. Instead, we covered a couple random topics.
Better classroom

Strengths: lectures were engaging, problem sets were practical and useful, professor regularly sought and incorporated student feedback into the course.
Weaknesses: the readings could have been more frequently referenced in class
While I recognize the importance of note taking, I found it difficult to transcribe the graphs and take notes to provide context. It would be helpful to have some pre-drawn graphs in the PowerPoints.

The assignments were both a strength and a weakness in that they helped solidify the material we learned in class but were sometimes frustrating and hard to figure out without going to office hours. I think the lectures were good- and I appreciate that Professor Kotchen encouraged us to participate in discussion and debate. I do think the material was occasionally very theoretical and I most appreciated when the material was tied to real-world examples.
I would put a higher emphasis on problem sets as they were the most powerful learning tools.
Try to avoid it. It will not push you or make you a better thinker.
be prepared to spend a lot of time on problem sets, but it's worth it because it's very interesting
I would recommend taking the class.  I would also suggest starting the problem sets early and going to TA office hours, which are very helpful.
Be prepared to spend anywhere between 2-4 hours on each week's homework assignment and plan on going to weekly office hours.

Don't worry about not having any foundational economics knowledge. All the concepts that you need will be covered in class and the topics are structured so that you build on the knowledge you've learned in the first few weeks. Work with your friends on problem sets and attend office hours and you'll be fine.
If it aligns with your interests, go for it.
Go to TA office hours for homework help.
Do the readings and solve the problem sets
Attend office hours!
Make sure you go to office hours if you don't understand concepts in the problem sets or class -- the TAs are super helpful!
Take advantage of office hours and study for tests.
The course is valuable regardless of what field you are focusing on. It is a good continuation of the fall required module, but dives into interesting and relevant environmental questions.

I would highly recommend this class. I would suggest that students in this class engage with the material in an intentional manner. I would also suggest forming study groups to work on the problem sets.
Go to class and you won't need to spend a long time working on the assignments
Its a great class! You'll come up with a good foundation in environmental economics and some interesting tools and case studies.

If you want to begin learning how to handle environmental policy and management questions using the tools of an economist, then this is a great course for you! If that is not what you want, you may find yourself frustrated. 

This is also a great foundational course to build on with other econ courses at FES (energy econ and policy, etc.).

Its an absolute must take course. 

However, students planning to take the class must be prepared to do weekly problem sets and written exams, unless the structure changes.
Take it!
Take it

Dedicate ample time to the problem sets and go to office hours. Even though the readings are not really covered in class or on the exams, completing them will enrich your understanding of the subject matter.

I would recommend taking this class for a good understanding of environmental economics. I would advise going to office hours as often as you can to talk about assignments with the TA and with classmates.
Take it! It is useful for any and every kind of environmental work.
